DOC.HEAD: Police: Bodies of Murdered Family Set On Fire
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday were looking to question a bicyclist seen riding near this small upstate New York town shortly before a family of four was shot to death and set afire in their suburban home. Warren Anthony Harris, 39, his wife, Delores, 41, their daughter, Shelby, 15, and son, Marc, 11, were found dead Saturday morning after neighbors in the affluent suburb of Ellis Hollow heard their fire alarm and called authorities. All four had been shot once through the head between 6 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. Friday. Police have given no motive for the crime, although they said some money may have been taken from the purse and wallet of the Harris couple. Investigators said there was no evidence of a break-in, but an inside telephone wire was pulled from the phone. A bicyclist riding in near zero-degree weather was seen at about 4:30 p.m. last Friday heading toward Dryden along a road where the family lived, state police said. A witness saw the bicyclist but could not describe the sex, race or age because the rider was wearing a parka, said Capt. Carl Shaver of the state police's Bureau of Criminal Investigations. Three of the victims were tied up in one room before being shot while the fourth was found on the floor of another room, said Capt. Robert J. Farrand, acting commander of state police Troop C. The bodies of all four then were doused with gasoline and set on fire, Farrand said. Violence is relatively uncommon in the area. The deaths raised the number of killings to only six this year around Ithaca, a city of 26,000 that is home to Cornell University. The Harrises lived between Ithaca and Dryden, about 10 miles to the east. The family's van was found Saturday about 5 miles east of their home at an Ithaca shopping center. Police believe the killer or killers used the van to flee. Shaver said he felt only one person was involved in the killings, but he said that had not been firmly established. Autopsies were begun Sunday at the Onondaga County Medical Examiner's office. Results were expected to be released Wednesday or Thursday, police said. ``They are doing an extremely thorough, detailed job,'' Shaver said. Medical examiners were looking not only for the cause of death but also for any indication of what happened to the Harrises before they were killed. Deanco Inc., an Ithaca-based electronics distributor where Warren Harris was employed as East Coast sales director, is offering a $5,000 reward for any information that leads to an arrest of the killer, state police said.
